title: When Grifters Hate Their Audience
description:
Finally, I can share with you all my response to, refutation of and analysis about Ben Shapiro's no-good-very-bad Superman (2025) review. This video will cover several of his videos about the topic, as well as an intro to the subject matter and the man himself. It contains debunks of his poor logic, elitist attitude and counterfactual arguments. It took a while to finally get this made, but now that it's finally out here I can move on to the last of this year's other projects. 2025 is almost done with us, but I'm not done with 2025. 

EDIT: A cut needed to be made in the clip where Shapiro summarizes the trailer due to Content ID claiming that section of the video and trying to pilfer all of the video's ad revenue. Sorry for the inconvenience.

title: Sinners: A Cost Paid Whitely
description:
YOU should watch Sinners NOW! This and other things everybody knew and nobody needed to be told, coming at you now in this video. This is my video, this is my essay, there are many like it but this one is mine. It's okay if you have a different reading of this film, there's like a dozen super duper valid ones, but I went with this one for no reason in particular. Lots of smarter YouTubers have talked about this film more intelligently, but I didn't want to not make a video about it. Sorry as always for the scuffed visuals, it's basically my brand at this point but Warner Bros blocked the video so I had to strip it of the original (transformed by the way) footage. Thanks to Ryan Coogler and the cast and crew for the good food. 

Kendi, Ibram X. How to Be an Antiracist. 1st ed., Random House, 2019.

This video was originally produced for my higher tier patrons over on Patreon for their exclusive video of September 2024. I've set out to talk about Dragon Age a whole bunch because I love it and because it's great. This time we're going over the first Dragon Age novel and how David Gaider adapted the feeling of the Dragon Age games to literature in the story of the rebel king, Maric.

title: Dragon Age Origins & The Trouble with Worldbuilding
description:
This video was originally produced for my higher tier patrons over on Patreon for their exclusive video of May 2024. I've had the itch to get back into this topic for a while, so I thought maybe a gentle look at one small piece of how worldbuilding affected the design of one of the Dragon Age games would be a good place to start. I rarely get to talk about writing on this channel, but this might also be a good chance to talk more Dragon Age. 

Kennedy, Alexis. Against Worldbuilding, and Other Provocations: Essays on History, Narrative and Game Design. Amazon Kindle Direct Publishing, 2021.

title: "The Presumed Straight Male Audience"
description:
Here's another short fun feminist analysis of video games, this time looking back at a dated argument about women, visual pleasure and audience frame of reference. You've heard it all before, but maybe not quite like this. I appreciate everyone's thoughtfulness and patience in approaching this, since it's a more dense and theoretical topic than some of what I usually discuss on this channel, and it would be impossible to say everything in a short video essay.

title: "Read Another Book" | Charitability and Young Adult Literature
description:
This video was originally intended to be uploaded the month after the events in question, specifically last September, but I got sick, then we had some family troubles I've already mentioned in the last video, then I got sick again, then I got busy over the holidays, and then I got sick again and started a bunch more projects, and here we are. As usual, do not direct any negativity towards any of the individuals mentioned in this video, especially because I agree with the majority of them and do not want to imply otherwise as I think they do good work. 

Gaming footage is from playthroughs of Greedfall, Dragon Age: The Veilguard, Batman: Arkham Asylum, Dark Souls 3, Resident Evil: Village and Borderlands 3, all of which will be the subject of future essays. The tarot card images are from the webpage linked below, and the Six of Crows playing cards are just the ones from the fandom wiki, so I have no idea how lore accurate they are. They do make my favorite characters look cool, though. 

RESOURCES: 
Bibliography: https://www.patreon.com/posts/in-defense-of-of-127475474?utm_medium=clipboard_copy&utm_source=copyLink&utm_campaign=postshare_creator&utm_content=join_link

title: The Truth About Anti-Woke Grifters
description:
I briefly entertained the idea of doing here what I did for the discourse around The Veilguard, but I decided to go above and beyond what I had previously attempted. Silly me. I wanted this to be out when it was more timely but that was too ambitious, so now, a month later, here's my big breakdown of everything I've learned from watching these discourses, complete with extensive citations. I even managed to keep it under three hours (technically). Lucky you. 

Gaming footage is from Assassin's Creed: Odyssey and Dragon Age: The Veilguard. Chapter headings contain audio from the following sources in order: Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood, the punch heard round the world, the George Lucas Mara Jade bit, the famous Lady Gaga interview with Anderson Cooper, the final showdown in Flight of the Dragons, Little Kuriboh's Yu-Gi-Oh! title: Ben Shapiro & "A Legacy of Failure" | The Last Jedi Videos, Part 8
description:
This is the eighth video in the "The Last Jedi Videos" series that I've been working on. In the first five videos, we focused more on the logical issues arising in the critiques made by various figures about various elements of the film. In the sixth video, we discussed the concepts of bad faith and grifting, and in the seventh video we broached the relationship of these ideas to conservatism when discussing the concept of "wokespotting." Now, a further discussion of conservatism, Star Wars, social issues and nostalgia is warranted. As always, the issue is not the TLJ is a good film or a bad film, but rather that given the poor quality of many arguments about it, the success of those arguments is conspicuous. What can we take away from all of this when considering this phenomenon broadly? That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre focused on here as we discuss everyone's favorite culture critic, Ben Shapiro. 

RESOURCES: 
Script & Bibliography: https://www.patreon.com/posts/111556294?pr=true 
Watch the other videos in this series: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoTilhtyRbhyDcLlg5c-cm3IdwbgH9uBh

title: Mr. Reagan & "A Child in a Mask" | The Last Jedi Videos, Part 7
description:
This is the seventh video in the "The Last Jedi Videos" series that I've been working on. In the first five videos, we focused more on the logical issues arising in the critiques made by various figures about various elements of the film. In the sixth video, we discussed the concepts of bad faith and grifting, which has naturally lead to this video about the concept of "wokespotting." As always, the issue is not the TLJ is a good film or a bad film, but rather that given the poor quality of many arguments about it, the success of those arguments is conspicuous. What can we take away from all of this when considering this phenomenon broadly? That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre focused on here as we discuss the channel ‚ÄúMr. Reagan‚Äù and its contributions to TLJ discourse.

title: The Soul of Ludopoetics | A Dark Souls Trilogy Retrospective
description:
I could have kept working on this for another half of a year, to be honest, but sometimes you have to know when to move on from a project, and I was trying so hard to get it down to around 3 or 4 hours. Oh well, maybe next time. This upload took forever to do thanks to my low tech setup and poor connection. I'd like if the audio quality and editing were better, but I'm just one person. 

This video was inspired by Demon Mama's stream attempts to beat the Dark Souls and From Software soulslikes for her audience, and by the immense passion that this community has inspired in me for these games. Aside from the wonderful creators I referenced in the video, my fabulous contributors and the amazing writers I quoted from, I would also like to dedicate this video to my former professor, Dr. Rejack, who first inspired me to start taking new media studies seriously. It is because of him that I have attempted with seriousness and anything resembling rigor to understand games and gaming on a deeper level. 

EDIT: The Bibliography is finally available in the description after a ~48 hour gap. The video has had some functionality and editing errors. Apologies again for the extra wait. One error in particular bears mentioning here. Readers should note that unfortunately in the visuals on screen, Greg Costikyan's last name was spelled incorrectly/inconsistently and has a "C" and not a "K" in it in the Bibliography. Apologies to the wonderful Mr. Costikyan for the error.

Music at the end during the credits has been muted (now partially, perhaps eventually fully) due to (false!) copyright claims on behalf of a record company which owns the rights to a hip-hop artist who sampled the Dark Souls track in question for a skit on their album. This is obviously an atrocious and blatant misuse of YouTube's Content ID system, but as there is no mechanism for disputing claims on the grounds that the claimant does not in fact own the disputed audio, I have opted to mute the video as opposed to losing 100% of what little revenue I gain to false claimants. Please understand. 

This video features the voices of the following creators who read the poetry sections! Go follow them!

title: In Defense of the Hobbit Trilogy
description:
Note to present and future patrons: as this video is over a week late, it contains patron names and thanks from yours truly that was due for the month of March. Further patron rewards will be forthcoming. Get in touch with me in DMs on Twitter if you have any questions or a reward you're interested in!
